description.narrative:
The overall objective: To increase the capacity of Oxfam and CCWG members to enhance the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (DONRE) and MONRE on the Implementation Plan of the Paris Agreement at national and provincial levels, with additional GHG emission reduction commitments in the next iteration of Vietnam#s NDC. This will focus on shifting the national energy profile towards renewable energy and advocating for rice models with mitigation co-benefits.
# Objective 1: Support national Government in their development and implementation of the action plan for Paris Agreement through introducing successful mitigation models in the energy and rice sectors that can be integrated into and informed by provincial action plans. o Output 1: Clearly identified needs and gaps of targeted provinces about their priority mitigation measures in energy and rice sectors within their own implementation of PA. o Output 2: A specific action plan for CCWG members to support the national Government on applying low-GHG emissions rice cultivation and energy strategies at the provincial and national level, which is integrated into PA Implementation Plan.
# Objective 2: Enhance cooperation and capacity for CCWG members on implementing low-emissions rice sector practices and renewable energy solutions to gain a stronger role in influencing policy makers regarding the mitigation component of the PA Implementation Plan. o Output 1: Mapping and documentation of successful models used by members of the CCWG regarding low-emissions rice cultivation and renewable energy; notonly in Vietnam but also at regional level such as ACCC network and IFI engagement, for sharing and advocacy in targeted provincesand at the national level. o Output 2: Existing successful models of CCWG members in the energy and rice sectors are introduced, integrated and applied in provincial action plan of PA, and at the national level.

participating-org.narrative: WWF has a long established presence in the Mekong region, starting in Vietnam in 1990. Since then, WWF operations have grown to five Country offices based in Cambodia (Phnom Penh), Laos (Vientiane), Thailand (Bangkok) <(>&<)> Vietnam (Hanoi), including a regionalteam in the Hanoi, Vientiane and Bangkok offices. The #Greater Mekong Programme Office# was officially formed in November 2005, merging WWF Indochina (Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam) and WWF Thailand. WWF was one of the first international non-government organisations working in Vietnam. In the 1990s, WWF-Vietnam began working on a national conservation strategy, and since then has worked closely with the Vietnamese government on a diverse range of environmental issues and implemented field activities acrosscountry.
